context: This could be related to the relatively small concentration of the biomarker. However, although a cross-sectional effect cannot be demonstrated in our study, a possible long-term effect on lung function should not be excluded, as demonstrated for environmental pollutants in other sites (Arossa et al., 1987). Adjusted by level of urbanization and passive smoke, also the diet, an important factor involved in the onset of oxidative stress, does not cause a different formation of 15-F2t-isoP among our subjects. The possible reason explaining the not confounder role of diet in the 15-F2t-isoP synthesis among the urbanized and not urbanized subjects, variously exposed to secondhand smoke, may be twofold. Firstly, the diet is very similar between all the students because the two population belong to the same school district which has two campuses, one in Chivasso (urban site) and one in Casalborgone (rural site). The lunch they consume in the school canteen is therefore the same and, since the samples were made in mid-week, we know that students consumed the lunches at school. Furthermore, the school meals were studied by nutritionists working at the local health authority to minimize oxidant food.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 8-epi-PGF2alpha is mentioned as a biomarker potentially related to oxidative stress and lung function, but the synthesis of this compound is not directly discussed. The text suggests that factors like diet and environmental exposure may influence the formation of 15-F2t-isoP, a related compound, rather than providing specific details on the synthesis of 8-epi-PGF2alpha itself. Thus, while there is an implied connection between oxidative stress and the synthesis of related compounds, the direct relationship between 8-epi-PGF2alpha and synthesis remains unclear.
